data.content: Fiction Friday
https://miro.medium.com/max/6000/0*fmAceXOuacPiGviw
Crap, I just rear-ended a car!
Now their door is opening…And Chris Chan steps out.
Chris and I partner up in science class a lot, but secretly I’ve wanted to, well, “partner up.” I hoped to leave an impression, but this isn’t what I had in mind!
Chris: HEY, WATCH THE ROAD.
Chris examines his car for dents and I stumble out.
Aishini: Chris, I’m sorry!
Chris: Aishini? Don’t worry, it’s not too beat up.
I sigh in relief.
Chris: How about you?
I examine the front of my car.
Aishini: It’s fine.
Chris: I guess we lucked out.
Aishini: I’m sorry I’m such a klutz.
Chris smirks.
Chris: Believe me, I know.
I blush. During a science experiment, I spilled water on Chris’s shirt.
Twice.
Chris: Hey, no harm no foul. Right?
He gives me a smile that always makes me giddy.
And then he notices the bags in my car.
Chris: Where are you headed?
Aishini: My friends go camping every summer.
Chris: At Spring View Park?
Aishini: That’s right!
Chris: I’m going there now. Stephanie invited me.
I feel a pit in my stomach. Stephanie asked him out? She KNOWS I like Chris!
I try to leave, but my car won’t start. Chris walks over.
Chris: I’d offer my condolences, but, then again, YOU crashed into ME.
I laugh a painful laugh. Chris eyes my hood.
Chris: Want me to check it? My dad’s a mechanic, so I know a few things.
Aishini: That would be great.
Chris rolls up his sleeves and opens my hood. I can’t help but stare.
Chris: This should do it.
He rises again with motor oil on his shirt.
Chris: You always ruin my shirts, Aishini.
He yanks it over his head. I stare at Chris Chan’s sculpted six-pack.
Aishini: You don’t need them.
Did I really just say that? Chris grabs a new shirt from his trunk.
Chris: Try the car again.
Yes, sir.
I turn the key in the ignition and it starts.
Chris: It was nothing.
Only the hottest thing ever.
Chris gives my car another look.
Chris: I still wouldn’t drive it.
Aishini: Why not?
Chris: I think it’s fixed, but I’d hate for it to break out there.
Aishini: Yeah, I’d be stranded at the park.
A part of me doesn’t want to go at all.
Chris: Park by the curb. I’ll have my dad look at it.
Chris moves my luggage into his trunk. A full car ride with him should be a dream. But now, with Stephanie’s shadow over us, it feels like torture.
Chris: What’s this?
He pulls my old, stuffed bear from the trunk. My face burns up.
Aishini: His name’s Fuzzy and he’s from my grandma.
Chris nods.
Chris: Fuzzy can ride shotgun.
I laugh.
Aishini: He’d like that.
We climb into Chris’s car. It’s intimate and smells like Chris. The doors close and I can hear our breaths.
Chris: You’ll be our navigator.
I give Chris a little salute.
Aishini: Yes, Captain.
He smiles and I grow giddy again. Why didn’t I ask him out sooner?
I’ll be pining over him this whole trip. The words just pour out of me:
Aishini: Can I say something?
Chris: Go for it.
My mouth dries up.
Aishini: I really love working together and you always make me feel so warm. I don’t know how you feel about Stephanie…But I just wanted to tell you.
Chris thinks.
Chris: That explains it.
Aishini: Explains what?
Chris: I should be pissed at being rear-ended, but I wasn’t. When you left your car, I felt…excited. I like you a lot, Aishini.
Aishini: But you like Stephanie too?
Chris surprises me with a laugh.
Chris: Not exactly. Stephanie invited me to meet her friend. Apparently, she’s had a big crush on me and we’re a perfect match.
His hand clasps over mine.
Chris: I think she may be right.
There’s little campfires twinkling in our eyes.
Chris caresses my cheek, and I take his face in my hands. It’s stubbly and soft and amazing. We finally kiss, tender but hungry. Our lips graze like our cars.
When we finally part, we’re both giddy.
Chris: Ready for camping?
Aishini: Right now, I’m ready for anything.
The End.
